headline: Jan. 6 Committee Subpoenas Trump Campaign Officials Over Fake Electors Scheme
author: Nicholas Reimann
sentences: The committee also subpoenaed Pennsylvania gubernatorial candidate and state Sen. Doug Mastriano (R), Arizona GOP chairwoman Kelli Ward, former Michigan Republican State Committee chairwoman Laura Cox and Arizona state Rep. Mark Finchem (R), who is also a member of the far-right militia group the Oath Keepers.

Topline
The House committee investigating the January 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol subpoenaed two former Trump campaign officials and four others Tuesday, claiming they have knowledge of an unsuccessful scheme to use false slates of electors to overturn the results of the 2020 presidential election.

Despite President Joe Biden winning Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, New Mexico, Nevada, Pennsylvania, and Wisconsin in 2020, Republicans in those states sent alternate slates of electors to D.C., falsely claiming their states Electoral College votes for Biden were illegitimate due to widespread fraud.

), chair of the House January 6 committee, said in a statement lawmakers believe the six have knowledge of or participated in? a scheme to send fake electors to Washington on January 6, 2021, to interfere with the certification of Electoral College votes.

One plan, called the Green Bay Sweep,? proposed that members of Congress draw out election certification proceedings for so long that then-Vice President Mike Pence would have been somehow forced to block the certification process entirely.

The Select Committee has heard from more than 550 witnesses, and we expect these six individuals to cooperate as well as we work to tell the American people the full story about the violence of January 6th and its causes,? Thompson said.
The committee last last month subpoenaed 14 swing-state Republicans who submitted alternate? electoral votes to Congress falsely saying former President Donald Trump won their states.
Ceremonies were even staged outside of statehouses where fake certificates were signed pledging electors for Trump, but the plan ultimately lacked any sort of legal backing.
The committee last week subpoenaed former White House trade advisor Peter Navarro over plots to overturn the election that he openly admitted to in a recent book.
The fake elector scheme is one of several plans to delay or overturn the election results, all of which appear legally groundless.

Key Facts
Michael Roman and G. Michael Brown, who served as top officials on Trump's 2020 campaign, were both given subpoenas.
Trumps former personal attorney, Rudy Giuliani, reportedly oversaw the fake elector scheme.
The committee subpoenaed Giuliani last month.
